content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												I had plenty of time to enjoy the Bioshock and Bioshock 2 series in the past week. I did not skip through the content like it was there for no reason, I've listened to audio logs, opened every chest in game and tried to kill everything that needed killing. I had a blast with Bioshock 1. Smooth experience, no crashes and an overall satisfaction. The end of Bioshock was kinda if-y but hey it was a really good game. Now what can I say about Bioshock 2? Well it was a great game, to be honest I liked the mechanics more than the first part and the story was so intense and beautiful that I got sucked into it and finished the game in 2 days. I will strongly suggest if you haven't played bioshock series to play do so.Now the problems with Bioshock 2.... O My F%#@*! GOD ! ! !First of all I had to spend quite some time figuring out a way to start the game since it was not loading at all and after a two days of brainstorming and forums-searching I found nothing. Then I've decided to delete it and re-install + the already unavailable Games for Windows Live and somehow, somewhat it started.The first 15 minutes of the game were awesome and suddenly CRASH ... like what ?!? Ok no problem I re-started the game and ... nope you've guessed it no auto save every 5 minutes or so, had to start from the beggining. This kept happening until I finished the game, every other hour or so I was getting a crash with no error message, no NOTHING. I did read some forums and tried all the turn off DX10 thing and resolution change and logs and well nothing helped. What I'd strongly reccomend is make QUICK SAVE on a keybind that you will be using atleast every 5-10 minutes, otherwise if you get sucked into the game and forget to save it it will return you back at your last auto save (which is either the beggining of the mission or a very important transition) and believe me after a while it gets frustrating (A LOT!!!).The game is intense if played on the right difficulty, the story is incredible and a good ending to the Bioshock series but the CRASHES are terrible and made me thing of leaving this game. Just finish it and I hope you don't have the same issues as I did but hey its the same thing, different pc :) (Windows 8.1 btw and my machine is really strong)Hope you enjoy the game and I wish it is a crash free experience for you :)

												Took me 3 tries to get into Bioshock 1.  Turned out to be a very good game.  Bioshock 2, to me, was a lot easier to get into.  I held out  on playing this one because it didn't have controller support, but it was recently patched in when GFWL was removed.  Graphics are slghtly better than the first.  They can be improved by using the NVIDIA Control Panel for better AA and AF.  You can also improve the slow control responsiveness by altering the .ini file.  The game also has well-know sound issues.  This doesn't take away the fact that it's a lot of fun to play through.  You're a big daddy, and you will need to make the same choice of rescuing or "adopting" the little sisters.  I rescue them all to get the "good" ending :)  Plasmids and tonics still a lot of fun to play with, and finding all the recordings is essential to follow the story.  Rapture looks great!  All in all, recommended.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
												While I do recommend this game, do not think that there are not some things that are less than acceptable =Story- The story is a bit more dumbed down then the first one. The gist of it is you’re a prototype Big Daddy who got resurrected and you need to find your little sister (now grown up). On your journey, you go through misadventure to misadventure. Overall, not the strongest out of the Bioshock seriesGameplay- Gameplay is more polished and improved from the first game. While there are very few new plasmids, the old ones are improved and have more development than the first game (For example, Electro Bolt at Level 3 can shoot a stream of electricity and chain lightning) Gunplay is also very fun, but some weapons are better left untouched at a Power to the People station than others. Overall, solid and entertainingGraphics- The models are a step up from the first game, now more polished and scary looking. Environments are similar to the first game, but with improved textures and a more abandoned feel. In sum, an upgrade from the first game.Control- The controls were fine. You can now duel wield a plasmid and a weapon. Switching weapons and plasmids in a fight could become tricky, but isn't a major fault that affects the game.Difficulty- Identical to the first game, with the added challenge of being limited to 5 medkits and 5 EVE hypos. Most of the time it’s a fair incline, but be prepared to gluttonously consume medkit after medkit during some fights.Polishes- Hacking is improved (Replacing long boring tube puzzles with quick button pressing) Plasmids are fun to use and they defiantly spice up the gameplay. Research is also more innovative, making the player contribute. Low Points- Games for Windows Live (GFWL) sucks. There, I said it. I recommend finding a way to disable it and adding -dx9 to launch options (Oh and stay away from multiplayer if you don't want a sour taste to be left in your mouth). Also, you can't go back to previous areas, so better scavenge the area well. Final Verdict: 7.5/10Bioshock 2 improves upon the first game (gameplay wise), making it more enjoyable to play. However, the games basic plot and lack of social/political commentary may leave some fans disappointed. If you want a game that improves upon the first gameplay wise, but lacks any real voice, I recommend this. Otherwise, it's best to save up $10.00 more to buy Infinite

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												I heard a lot of bad things about Bioshock 2 when it came out so never bothered to pick it up. Years later when I grabbed the aging title in the steam sales, I got a lot of "omg you're playing that?" remarks.  These comments were taken with a grain of salt, particularly given that some of the naysayers had never played the game. Nevertheless they weren't exactly wrong.As it turned out, it's not actually a bad game. It's just not as good as Bioshock1, and if I had bought it full price I'd have been far less pleased.There's no real innovation and frankly being a big slow clumpy metal man is a bit of a drag after having played the original mostly with stealth and traps. Yes, there are clyclone traps, but these were not all that useable in the end.Throughout the game II found myself constantly having to pop health packs, switch weapons who’s ammo capacity was abysmal, and avoiding enemy fire with line of sight. This rendered the "gimmik" of Project Delta, the main protagonist, rather unusable. What's the point of having a nifty giant drill attack if using it will put you in close quarters out in the open losing a good chunk of your health, and the "ammo" runs out quicker than you can say “this all looks the same.”There are a shockingly low number of enemy unit types. Sure,  there are a few minor variations on the models, but the actual types? Very few. There's little in the way of environment either, with many assets seemingly plucked straight from the original and no real care having gone into differentiating the new parts of rapture you’re visiting from those you entered in BS1. All in all, the story is decent, and the voice overs very good. What lets the game down is the game design Not nearly enough thought was put into "is this actually FUN."By the end, I was simply glad the whole thing was over (it's quite long if you explore) and I could move on to biosock infinite, so I made no moves towards the DLC, or multiplayer.If you can get the game for less than 5 euro, it’s worth it if you liked bioshock 1. Turn the difficulty down to easy, and just mindlessly blast your way through while following the story.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												A worthy sequel.  Visually and mechanically a step up from the original Bioshock, though the story is a bit too convoluted for it's own good.  The combat is notably improved, and sticking splicers to a wall with a speargun is immensely satisfying.  The city of Rapture is more colorful and feels larger thanks to the giant windows and the walks on the bottom of the ocean.  It does feel a bit "gamey"; there are abundant set pieces and it's quite clear where one level ends and the next begins.  The addition of guarding a Little Sister as she harvests Adam from a dead body is novel at first, but wears thin after the third or fourth time.  Then you have to do it about a dozen more...  That's this game in a nutshell; if you liked the first game it's a safe bet you'll like this, but the "been there, done that" feeling does set in after a time.  The DLC (Minerva's Den) is not a bad crash course into Rapture either.  It crashed on a me a couple times and I had to disable DirectX 10 effects to get through it, so the noticeable visual downgrade didn't do it any favors.  Still enjoyable, however, even if it feels like a disconnected story set in the Bioshock universe.  The ion cannon and singularity plasmid are highlights.  My main complaint (besides the crashing) is the muddy objectives which lead to feeling like you're a rat in a maze at times.  If you can get it rather cheap and aren't burned out on the series it's certainly worth checking out.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Most things from BioShock apply to BioShock 2, so I'll do the rundown on changes.2 Quick discalimers:1-It crashes, a lot, and seemingly for no reason. It doesn't autosave as much as I wanted it to, so save often!2-The scarier moments from BioShock are pretty much gone (make of that what you will), so if you're not a horror fan, you'll probably enjoy this a bit more than BioShock, but it's still pretty bloody.So you're a Big Daddy by the name of 'Subject Delta', but you can still use Plasmids and such, because your a prototype. Your little sister, now a grown-up sister, needs your help after you get ressurected. The story is above average, but overall weaker than BioShock. Similar progression to BioShock as well, semi-linear missions but plenty of exploring for cakes and ammo. We've also got some new characters to go with our new areas too. Another change I like is the visual style. Set 8 years after BioShock, Rapture's leak problem has got a little...bigger...to say the least. The art deco style has been preserved, but there's odd glowing underwater plants and stuff, and the sequences where you get to wander around on the ocean floor are really beautiful. I spent the first 10-ish minutes going 'Whoa, everything's so pretty!'.Gameplay is largely the same, except now we can dual wield Plasmids and Weapons, a much needed improvement, and a full new host of weapons as well. Plasmids are largely the same, but some changes and additions, usual sequel things. I also found I was using a greater variety of weapons and Plasmids than BioShock, where I was often just using Electro-Bolt and the Machine Gun, Gene tonics are more streamlined, so you only have 1 HUGE set of Gene Tonics, which is rather nice as in BioShock, I was often thinking 'gawd, I need more combat tonic slots!'. Hacking isn't total♥♥♥♥♥♥anymore, just a kinda Quicktime event, but you can still screw up, and you can also hack from a distance, hooray! Enemies are largely the same, two new types of Big Daddy and one new Splicer is all I've seen so far. So pretty solid all round, nothing too different from the original, but some much needed changes.However, BioShock 2 does have a fair swathe of problems. The story isn't as good as before, which is a real weakness. The main antagonist has the most annoying voice ever, and she's always around, but the other characters are fine. As a Big Daddy, when you get to a Little Sister, you have two options: 1-'Adopt' her, take her to a corpse, gather some ADAM as you munch through half your health and Ammo after fighting a butt-ton of Splicers, then do it again, and finally send her to a vent, and I don't think you even get rewards unlike BioShock. Or, 2-Kill her on the spot, 120 ADAM, bam, no fuss, lots of mess, but no uneccesary usage of Health kits.On the note of Health and EVE Hypos: You can only carry 5 of each, but First Aid Kits fully heal you. I found I was often low of health. And it annoys me how you can eat, drink and smoke through your steel diving helmet, unless Subject Delta can absorb nutrients through Osmosis or something.When you are dealing with Little Sisters, there's a chance it can summon a Big Sister, a kind of Mini-Boss. They're kind of annoying, but not a huge♥♥♥♥♥♥to deal, and you are given proper warning. But please, ONLY spawn one if we're being evil and harvesting them, NOT protecting them with our lives and finally freeing them from their torment.The other two problems are more technical. I found the Audio was very quiet, everything was quite distant most of the time, which is really annoying, especially when sound is so important. The other problem is buttons. Although being able to dual wield is nice, there's a lot of extra keys, and it can get a bit cluttered. Due to too many keys, there's no manual way to reload EVE, which is a real pain in the middle of a fight, so you have to zap yourself to 0, then reload, which is about as fast as the original.But overall, BioShock 2 is still solid. It's kind of like Portal and Portal 2. They're both good games, but BioShock is superior to BioShock 2. The story is less tight than before, and there's some dangling threads here and there. BioShock 2 also has the morality element present, but it's handled a lot better, a bit more grey. And I genuinelly felt sad with the ending I got.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Most things from BioShock apply to BioShock 2, so I'll do the rundown on changes.2 Quick discalimers:1-It crashes, a lot, and seemingly for no reason. It doesn't autosave as much as I wanted it to, so save often!2-The scarier moments from BioShock are pretty much gone (make of that what you will), so if you're not a horror fan, you'll probably enjoy this a bit more than BioShock, but it's still pretty bloody.So you're a Big Daddy by the name of 'Subject Delta', but you can still use Plasmids and such, because your a prototype. Your little sister, now a grown-up sister, needs your help after you get ressurected. The story is above average, but overall weaker than BioShock. Similar progression to BioShock as well, semi-linear missions but plenty of exploring for cakes and ammo. We've also got some new characters to go with our new areas too. Another change I like is the visual style. Set 8 years after BioShock, Rapture's leak problem has got a little...bigger...to say the least. The art deco style has been preserved, but there's odd glowing underwater plants and stuff, and the sequences where you get to wander around on the ocean floor are really beautiful. I spent the first 10-ish minutes going 'Whoa, everything's so pretty!'.Gameplay is largely the same, except now we can dual wield Plasmids and Weapons, a much needed improvement, and a full new host of weapons as well. Plasmids are largely the same, but some changes and additions, usual sequel things. I also found I was using a greater variety of weapons and Plasmids than BioShock, where I was often just using Electro-Bolt and the Machine Gun, Gene tonics are more streamlined, so you only have 1 HUGE set of Gene Tonics, which is rather nice as in BioShock, I was often thinking 'gawd, I need more combat tonic slots!'. Hacking isn't total♥♥♥♥♥♥anymore, just a kinda Quicktime event, but you can still screw up, and you can also hack from a distance, hooray! Enemies are largely the same, two new types of Big Daddy and one new Splicer is all I've seen so far. So pretty solid all round, nothing too different from the original, but some much needed changes.However, BioShock 2 does have a fair swathe of problems. The story isn't as good as before, which is a real weakness. The main antagonist has the most annoying voice ever, and she's always around, but the other characters are fine. As a Big Daddy, when you get to a Little Sister, you have two options: 1-'Adopt' her, take her to a corpse, gather some ADAM as you munch through half your health and Ammo after fighting a butt-ton of Splicers, then do it again, and finally send her to a vent, and I don't think you even get rewards unlike BioShock. Or, 2-Kill her on the spot, 120 ADAM, bam, no fuss, lots of mess, but no uneccesary usage of Health kits.On the note of Health and EVE Hypos: You can only carry 5 of each, but First Aid Kits fully heal you. I found I was often low of health. And it annoys me how you can eat, drink and smoke through your steel diving helmet, unless Subject Delta can absorb nutrients through Osmosis or something.When you are dealing with Little Sisters, there's a chance it can summon a Big Sister, a kind of Mini-Boss. They're kind of annoying, but not a huge♥♥♥♥♥♥to deal, and you are given proper warning. But please, ONLY spawn one if we're being evil and harvesting them, NOT protecting them with our lives and finally freeing them from their torment.The other two problems are more technical. I found the Audio was very quiet, everything was quite distant most of the time, which is really annoying, especially when sound is so important. The other problem is buttons. Although being able to dual wield is nice, there's a lot of extra keys, and it can get a bit cluttered. Due to too many keys, there's no manual way to reload EVE, which is a real pain in the middle of a fight, so you have to zap yourself to 0, then reload, which is about as fast as the original.But overall, BioShock 2 is still solid. It's kind of like Portal and Portal 2. They're both good games, but BioShock is superior to BioShock 2. The story is less tight than before, and there's some dangling threads here and there. BioShock 2 also has the morality element present, but it's handled a lot better, a bit more grey. And I genuinelly felt sad with the ending I got.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												I heard a lot of bad things about Bioshock 2 when it came out so never bothered to pick it up. Years later when I grabbed the aging title in the steam sales, I got a lot of "omg you're playing that?" remarks.  These comments were taken with a grain of salt, particularly given that some of the naysayers had never played the game. Nevertheless they weren't exactly wrong.As it turned out, it's not actually a bad game. It's just not as good as Bioshock1, and if I had bought it full price I'd have been far less pleased.There's no real innovation and frankly being a big slow clumpy metal man is a bit of a drag after having played the original mostly with stealth and traps. Yes, there are clyclone traps, but these were not all that useable in the end.Throughout the game II found myself constantly having to pop health packs, switch weapons who’s ammo capacity was abysmal, and avoiding enemy fire with line of sight. This rendered the "gimmik" of Project Delta, the main protagonist, rather unusable. What's the point of having a nifty giant drill attack if using it will put you in close quarters out in the open losing a good chunk of your health, and the "ammo" runs out quicker than you can say “this all looks the same.”There are a shockingly low number of enemy unit types. Sure,  there are a few minor variations on the models, but the actual types? Very few. There's little in the way of environment either, with many assets seemingly plucked straight from the original and no real care having gone into differentiating the new parts of rapture you’re visiting from those you entered in BS1. All in all, the story is decent, and the voice overs very good. What lets the game down is the game design Not nearly enough thought was put into "is this actually FUN."By the end, I was simply glad the whole thing was over (it's quite long if you explore) and I could move on to biosock infinite, so I made no moves towards the DLC, or multiplayer.If you can get the game for less than 5 euro, it’s worth it if you liked bioshock 1. Turn the difficulty down to easy, and just mindlessly blast your way through while following the story.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
   Underwater Fun and Fighting   After completing BioShock 2 and the Minervas Den DLC I think I can now give an unbiased review of both.BioShock 2 was a delightful journey through Rapture, following the events of the 1st in the series. and taking a new twist on the main protaganist and their motivations.There was a steady learning curve, allowing you to build a unique set of skills that include weapons, Plasmids (powers) and perks.  The weapons were varied and the upgrades made a serious change to the basic weapon - the shotgun being suprisingly meaty as it became upgraded.The Plasmids provide enough for whatever playstyle you prefer; ranging from telekenisis to freezing the baddies in their tracks.The addition of the other perks, meant that hacking and use of the drill in more 'intimate' fights, became as important as each other.As always the story develops over several characters, providing a few twists and turns I didn't expect, and it's the 'life' in each charater that serioulsy influences some of the choices that come on offer.  You can be mad, bad and a nasty piece of work, or make alternative choices and be rewarded for your human nature side.I took about 23 hours but did choose to explore and go looking in every nook and cranny (very recommended), but the dying was never so frustrating you wanted to stop.  Some fights lead to several deaths, but a quick swap of tactics and you're out there in the fray again.Minerva's Den is a decent sized DLC (8 hours?) that tells a completly new story, with no mention of the main game.  This allows the writers to put in different characters and make it a "BioSHock 2 Light", with none of the research side of the main game (it's assumed that you know what Houdini Splicer is etc. but the rules are to just kill whatever is shooting at you, so little knowledge of the baddies is really needed).  You will get many hours of fun and get into some real scrapes along the way.Graphics are pretty good on a decent system that can throw the polygons around, the water effects (as you'd expect) are superb, as are the particle and smoke effects.The sound is amazing and really embeds the player into a post-war environment.All in all a sound 9/10.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2016
												7.8/10The story was detailed enough to peak your interest, but the overall linearity of going from trainstop to trainstop do the task and move on was relatively dull. However the tasks did prove fruitful and the satisfaction of getting stronger; finding new tonics/ plasmids was worth the exploration. Players who are new to Bioshock or fps in general, could find the game somewhat challenging due to the lack of knowledge in when to use your heals/eves. Or perhaps that they are fairly scare. The conservation of ammuntiton is important, which correlates to your accuracy, as the more you use the less you would have for other possibly difficult opponents-obviously. In essence the gameplay is enjoyable and allows you to follow the character with some empathy, the change in perspective during the game does ease the normal steampunk environment which can be refreshing. What was lacking was the depth in the story and environment as it wasn't impactful enough and with no clarity in freedom leaves the players to just move forward.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
   Underwater Fun and Fighting   After completing BioShock 2 and the Minervas Den DLC I think I can now give an unbiased review of both.BioShock 2 was a delightful journey through Rapture, following the events of the 1st in the series. and taking a new twist on the main protaganist and their motivations.There was a steady learning curve, allowing you to build a unique set of skills that include weapons, Plasmids (powers) and perks.  The weapons were varied and the upgrades made a serious change to the basic weapon - the shotgun being suprisingly meaty as it became upgraded.The Plasmids provide enough for whatever playstyle you prefer; ranging from telekenisis to freezing the baddies in their tracks.The addition of the other perks, meant that hacking and use of the drill in more 'intimate' fights, became as important as each other.As always the story develops over several characters, providing a few twists and turns I didn't expect, and it's the 'life' in each charater that serioulsy influences some of the choices that come on offer.  You can be mad, bad and a nasty piece of work, or make alternative choices and be rewarded for your human nature side.I took about 23 hours but did choose to explore and go looking in every nook and cranny (very recommended), but the dying was never so frustrating you wanted to stop.  Some fights lead to several deaths, but a quick swap of tactics and you're out there in the fray again.Minerva's Den is a decent sized DLC (8 hours?) that tells a completly new story, with no mention of the main game.  This allows the writers to put in different characters and make it a "BioSHock 2 Light", with none of the research side of the main game (it's assumed that you know what Houdini Splicer is etc. but the rules are to just kill whatever is shooting at you, so little knowledge of the baddies is really needed).  You will get many hours of fun and get into some real scrapes along the way.Graphics are pretty good on a decent system that can throw the polygons around, the water effects (as you'd expect) are superb, as are the particle and smoke effects.The sound is amazing and really embeds the player into a post-war environment.All in all a sound 9/10.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2016
												This game is totally bonkers. Kooky, wacky, and super fun. I went into this one not knowing anything about the Bioshock universe and what a great surprise this turned out to be. Bioshock 2 is unlike anything I was expecting. I dig it.A Howard Huges type industrialist decides it would be a great idea to build New York City deep in the ocean, post World War II. The seafloor city he creates is called Rapture. Over the years everyone who moves in ends up going nuts. The citizens find out a sea slug can be turned into underwater super-meth so they end up addicted as 1950s era zombie drug fiends wearing tuxedos and cocktail dresses. And they join a cult. It's kinda rad. Nobody is keeping up with any building repairs so the whole city is falling apart- and flooding. Rapture's underwater city scape is a nice mix of run down collapsing atomic age buildings and colorful exterior seafloor areas. It's got a nice atmosphere complete with a big band soundtrack and lots of corny fifties kitch that works really well in-game. It reminded me somewhat of Fallout 3 with regard to the black humor and goofy vintage advertisements all over the place. On a side note I'd recommend playing both Bioshock 2 and Fallout 3 back to back. They compliment each other well.In Bioshock 2 you are a weirdo deep sea construction worker with bad breath roaming around in a metal diving suit called 'Big Daddy'. You've got a decade old headache... the underwater bad guys punked you and ripped off your kid. So it's understandable why you are a hater and extra pi$$ed off. You also happen to have some serious telekinetic powers plus a gnarley drill you can gut people with. That's just for starters. Later on you'll pick up a rivet gun, an antique shotgun, a spear gun, and some other odd weapon doo-dads that will put the hurt on hipster brainwashed junkies. Your job is to wreck these jerks and reunite with your little sister. Easy beans, right?The game has a setup whereby you can choose what weapons you want to upgrade incrementally, but there are a limited amount of upgrades available on each level. So choose wisely. Another interesting dynamic is you can literally make the game more difficult on the fly by triggering more boss fights. Attack other Big Daddies as you encounter them to adopt their kid (little sister), or not. If you do whack 'em and snag their little sister you have another choice available to either rescue them or pimp 'em out and harvest the loot. Rescue them enough times and you trigger yet another boss fight. That's pretty cool because you can make the game more painful with more boss fights and get rewarded accordingly or make it easier and not have to brawl as much. It's entirely up to you how you want to play it. The benefit to taking the long hard road and making it tough is you get loot to upgrade your telekinetic powers. One of my favorites turned out to be Hypnotize. Roll into a room with a handful of junkies wandering around loose and Hypnotize them to start an entertaining prison brawl. You can kick back and snag the loot when it's all over.Due to a fair amount of complaints about the Bioshock 2 Remastered version not working well or at all because of a ton of bugs and glitches I decided to play the regular version on my system. The regular version of Bioshock 2 was super stable with no issues to report.

												While it was similar to its predecessor Bioshock 2 still came through with a new and interesting experience. While gameplay was more or less the same, the story that they came up with was as interesting as it was engaging. I felt very satisfied with the amount of gameplay (about 8-10 hours), where I was content with the story ending when it did but also at a point where I was not sick of the game and just wanted it to end. I actually feel like playing through the game (taking different actions this time too). Now while the graphics where more like the first Bioshock that didnt bug me. I liked the look of rapture and this gave me more of the same. I didnt feel like I was playing a different game, I in fact liked the idea of being able to play Bioshock then start playing Bioshock 2 right away and feel like Im still in the same decaying city of Rapture. I dont see why a game series always has to up the graphics in each game to the point where there is a significant difference. Now I see it as a good thing if theres a significant difference between games but we see games from other companies (IE valve) where continiuing with the same graphics really give you sense of the environment. Now I also see it as a good idea to update when you change that environment such as with Bioshock Infinite. There was a few story elements that I didnt like but not to the point that it bothered me. But I really liked how you learn more about Rapture and they even tied in the main character from Bioshock. I went in expecting a game similar yet different from Bioshock, and I got that and more.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2014
												(Recommended despite 'boss battle' overload and incongruous vulnerability)Bioshock 2 is not as innovative, cohesive and thematically sophisticated as the original. That being said, it plays just as well, if not better, due to some much needed design modifications. And the game looks markedly better as well. Its problems lie in the storyline and how it progresses. While the communism v.s. objectivism theme sounds fantastic on paper, it is not as convincing as Bioshock's treatment of objectivism and capitalism. Perhaps it reveals that Ken Levine knew what he was writing about, whereas Bioshock 2 better resembles a summary of Wikipedia pages on the subject. But, if you're there for the gameplay and experience itself, you'll be happy. Combat is smoother; the environment is more detailed and traversing it is more challenging. However, the means to obtain Adam soon grows very tedious.Remember that section in the first game when you protected a little sister against waves of enemies? In the second game, you don't have a little sister until you defeat another big daddy and take his. Naturally, the combat here is very challenging. However, if you harvest the little sister right then and there, you'll get very little return. Instead, you must let her extract Adam from three designated corpses in the area; each time, you are beset at all sides by enemies who only become stronger the further you advance through the game. Of course, after doing this three times, you are met with the same binary choice as in the first game: harvest or set-free. But don't forget, each area has three big daddies and three little sisters. Once all little sisters are harvested or freed in an area, you'll be forced into an immediate fight to the death with a big sister.This is what I mean by 'boss battle overload', and it's all the more confusing that the character you're playing should, by all means, BE a boss! It certainly doesn't feel so, as you die just as easily as any human. So, unless you LOVE this gameplay mechanic, you might come to hate hearing the words, "look daddy, it's an angel!" That being said, certainly persevere with the game. You just might like to save the expansion, Minerva's Den for a while later.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2016
												Bioshock 2: Taken Edition.The original Bioshock needs little explanation for its initial success. A curveball in the field of story-based first person shooters, the strong direction and risks it took to shake up the standard makes it an oft-remembered title. Between the success of the original and the ever-so-popular Bioshock: Infinite, it seems odd how much Bioshock 2 comes off as the black sheep of the family. While well-lauded with some minor critiques back in the day, it comes off as an afterthought compared to the rest of its namesake. "Oh, right, Bioshock 2 exists," was my initial reaction when I bought the Bioshock package deal during a sale. As I began playing, I found myself rather surprised just how much more I enjoyed this over its predescessor.The story starts off with a bang and the plot goes as follows: You are a Big Daddy (and so will be for the entire course of the game) that's on the hunt for his Little Sister. The Objectivist, libertarian "paradise" of the former game has crumbled and given way to a despotic autocracy under the guise of a theocratic Utopia. While the game starts off slowly to ease you in, it doesn't take long for it to find its stride. The first thing I noticed was how much more lively this rendition of Rapture felt. Unlike in the first game where every unique NPC was either behind a glass window or part of a cutscene, you are given the choice of dealing with them as you so wish. Audio diaries abound, the enemies themselves have an incredible amount of lines, everything in general is more talkative. Well, save for the vending machines, they did away with the whole "WELCOME TO THE CIIIIRCUS OF VALUUUES!" schtick for better or worse. It can be a little overwhelming at times, since there were a few times where the intercom would interrupt an audio diary I was listening to or something else of the sort will take over. I won't touch on the ending in detail, but I will say that it's certainly better than the 30 second one from the first.However, the biggest improvement from the first game lies in the gameplay itself. Long gone are the loose gun controls and odd hit detection for snug shooting and bashing, and with those improvements comes better plasmids, more weapons, and a (thankfully) fun research system. No longer will you have to bust your camera out and take pictures of the enemy - now you get style points for throwing everything at them. My favorite change is the fact that you can have both a plasmid and a weapon out at the same time - you no longer have to switch between the two. The levels themselves are more complex and massive than the first one, which was fairly linear in comparison. One thing I want to nitpick is the fact that you cannot feasibly get every plasmid in the game or upgrade all your weapons, as there are simply not enough stations or ADAM to go around. Outside of that, everything is an improvement.Graphically, there are some reused assets as to be expected, but the models are sharp and less cartoonish than in the first Bioshock. The setpieces and underwater sections are gorgeous, and as a plus, the textures aren't as muddied. And while the frequency of the old-fashioned tunes have taken a nosedive, the ambience and fight music have been tweaked to be more noticeable and rousing. Too often, video game scores are generic and cookie-cutter to be anything more than a part of an "EPIC GAME MUSIC COMPILATION - THE BEST" Youtube video. On that front, I found myself looking up certain tracks because they were that damn good.Even so, there are some elements that I did not enjoy. More specifically, the way of gathering ADAM is a chore. You plop a Little Sister down and kill wave after wave of splicers before picking the little♥♥♥♥♥♥back up and going on your way to another corpse. Some of the symbolism thrown at you in the course of the game is about as subtle as a deer looking into the headlights of an incoming semi, and the main villain doesn't even feel particularly rancorous. While you got taunted and jeered at in the first game, the antagonist in this one might as well just say, "Oh dear, you survived again. Oh well, let me repeat my ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t diatribe again, since I am totally in the right again." The last time around, you had every reason to gut the villain. This time, you just go, "Well, okay, good for you." Plus, there are some twists and turns that might catch some people off-guard and be too reaching, but again, that's up to personal preference.Bioshock 2, even with its share of quirks, is what a sequel should be like. It hits all of the high notes while adjusting a lot of the lower ones. Go get it in the bundle deal, it's dirt cheap.(Also, multiplayer is deader than a doorknob. If you like your achievements, I hope you either enjoy wrangling up a bunch of friends to play it or altering around some files for those 'cheevos!)8.5/10.

content:
Posted: June 1, 2016
												I\'m mostly going to be focusing Multiplayer part of the game. The singleplayer was great and I\'d definitely give it a shot if you haven\'t played it yet. It\'s pretty much like the first game, but with improved gameplay. The Multiplayer is gay though. Here\'s why.First of all, it is one of the most unbalanced multiplayer games of all time. New players aren\'t going to stand a chance because they don\'t know how the game works and all the cheap tatics the experienced players use, and they don\'t have good equipment. It\'s completely unfair. The best weapons I would recommend from my experience are the grenade launcher with any upgrade, except homing grenades, the elephant gun with the quad barrel upgrade for headshots, the crossbow with the rate of fire upgrade, or you could use any other upgrade for headshots. I\'d recommend the pistol with any upgrade if you have good aim. You also can\'t go wrong with the shotty. My favorite plasmids are electrobolt to stun opponents(works great with headshots), Aero Dash to get around faster and to confuse your opponents. Dash can also get you out of electro-stuns, fire,bees and away from turrets. Telekinesis is probably the best plasmid. It can catch grenades and arrows, freeze players for a second and make insta-kills with it. Winter Blast is good too because it can slow players so you can get some good shots on them. Incinerate also works great with the grenade launcher. The gene tonics I always use are eve saver, fast feet and head hunter. I wouldn\'t use head hunter if you\'re not planning to make headshots with the grenade launcher or crossbow. Practice and experimenting with new loadouts and seeing which ones you like best will make you a good player. If you have the patience to play until you unlock all these things then my hat\'s off to you. But really, the unlocking system this game uses makes it hard for new players to enjoy and keep playing this game.The other huge problem with this game is all the bugs, glitches and the overall way it is set up. The game suffers from neglect by its developers. The game often lags and crashes due to the player-to-player hosting it uses. There\'s nothing you can do about a bad host or a rage quitter other than ask them to rejoin or wait for them to leave or just start a new lobby if you can get enough players. The game also doesn\'t have any type of protection against cheaters, spammers and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. Unfortunately, there are lots of those players, so all you can really do to avoid playing with them is wait for them to leave or start a private game and hope they won\'t find a way in. It doesn\'t even have a mute option. By the way, if you\'re using a microphone and it\'s making noise in the game, please turn it it down. You can do this by going to Steam Settings, voice, and turn the slider all the way to the left. Please, nobody wants to have to listen to your♥♥♥♥♥♥while they\'re playing.It\'s an old game. The devs didn\'t put a lot of work into it.  It\'s small and needs more guns and new things, but most of all, it needs A LOT of work. Hopefully one day 2K or someone will remember this game and fix it, but that\'s probably never going to happen. I\'d try this game if you want something different.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
												Bioshock 2 places the player back in the undersea world of Rapture.  The game takes place several years after the events of the first game.  In this game you play as Subject Delta, a Big Daddy that is trying to find his Little Sister.  There is more to it, but I'd rather avoid any major spoilers.Rapture looks better than ever in the second entry of the series.  The graphics have been improved in every way.  There isn't any undersea combat, but walking around at the bottom of the sea was a beautiful experience.  The combat and controls have been vastly improved in every way.  Although it was sad to see that the old hacking system was removed, the new one keeps you in battle and has a far more fluid feeling.  The story isn't as interesting as it was in the previous game, but it is far from bad.  They probably should have fleshed out the story from the Minvera's Den DLC and used it for the base game instead.Despite all of the positive aspects of this game, I cannot recommend it.  I don't know if this game is a sloppy console port, but it sure feels like one.  I played this with a GTX 960 (a much better video card than the suggested 8800 GT) and I thought my computer was going to have a meltdown.  The game runs so poorly that the developers should be ashamed.  I spent some time reading other reviews and it doesn't seem like I'm the only person that has had this issue.  I rushed through the game because I was concerned about the strain it was placing on my computer even after drastically reducing the settings. Sad, it might have been fun to play through a second time.If it weren't for the performance issues I would recommend this one. Alas, here we are.  Purchase and play this game at your own risk.

Not content with awful 64 bit support, the disc version of the game stopped activating when Securom was driven back to hell. Activate the game code in Steam though and everything works fine. Bioshocks 1 and Infinite ("BS" and "Limited" would be better names) may both start with a fanfare and progress with  mighty crescendos, but they soon forget the tune, bore with repetition and end with a spluttering fart. Rarely have games promised so much high concept and delivered so little gameplay. Bioshock 2 is different. You're just dropped straight in and told to get on with it. It's a little underwhelming to start, but the game progresses well. You gather a varied arsenal of plasmids and weapons, upgrade them, explore the non-linear levels at your leisure, and have the opportunity to plan every takedown of the bigger guys and girls. It's all rather satisfying, which was quite a surprise. Even that damn pipemania hacking thing has gone. And your droids have names like Phyllis and Nathaniel (who said I wasn't easily pleased?). In summary, it's hard to see why this gets lower reviews than the other two, but that's the consequence of putting gameplay above glitz. 6/10. Minerva's Den is more of the same with some new stuff, but an odd tendency to crash occasionally. 6/10.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												Compared to Bioshock 1 I found that BS2 is a fantastic sequel which fixes all the bad gameplay ideas from the first game and adds it's own flavor to things. The story is deep and twisted and you should play the first game before this to enjoy it to the fullest. Gameplay: Moving/shooting is solid and weapons really do damage unlike in BS1. You have a lot of choices with weapon upgrades and plasmids (sort of magic in BS-world) and you can make your own "character build" to some extent. You can use different approaches when it comes to encountering enemies i.e. hacking security cams to make the enemies trigger the alerts instead of you, shooting through the corridors or confusing your enemies to fight each other with plasmids. Story: Story is dark and gritty and mostly presented with audio recordings. This isn't necessarily the best way to tackle the storytelling but you will be rewarded with a lush backstory if you have the patience to listen. SummaryPros:-Graphix still pretty-Improved gun-/plasmidplay-Story-Atmosphere -All the different options and upgrades Cons: -Story told mostly by audio recordings-No one plays the multiplayer anymore-I encountered some serious crashing during two last levels and lost 3 hours worth of progress. Because of this I encourage everyone to quicksave/save constantly to avoid such thing. Too bad they won't probably be fixing this major problem anymore...Overral a brilliant game that suffers some serious bugs (later in the game for me).

content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
												Bioshock 2 places the player back in the undersea world of Rapture.  The game takes place several years after the events of the first game.  In this game you play as Subject Delta, a Big Daddy that is trying to find his Little Sister.  There is more to it, but I'd rather avoid any major spoilers.Rapture looks better than ever in the second entry of the series.  The graphics have been improved in every way.  There isn't any undersea combat, but walking around at the bottom of the sea was a beautiful experience.  The combat and controls have been vastly improved in every way.  Although it was sad to see that the old hacking system was removed, the new one keeps you in battle and has a far more fluid feeling.  The story isn't as interesting as it was in the previous game, but it is far from bad.  They probably should have fleshed out the story from the Minvera's Den DLC and used it for the base game instead.Despite all of the positive aspects of this game, I cannot recommend it.  I don't know if this game is a sloppy console port, but it sure feels like one.  I played this with a GTX 960 (a much better video card than the suggested 8800 GT) and I thought my computer was going to have a meltdown.  The game runs so poorly that the developers should be ashamed.  I spent some time reading other reviews and it doesn't seem like I'm the only person that has had this issue.  I rushed through the game because I was concerned about the strain it was placing on my computer even after drastically reducing the settings. Sad, it might have been fun to play through a second time.If it weren't for the performance issues I would recommend this one. Alas, here we are.  Purchase and play this game at your own risk.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												Is this game better than the original?That's hard to say. It's certainly an excellent game. The graphics remain beautiful, the shooting is great, and the melee combat is an improvement. Is the plot better? For this, I would say no. I'm not saying that the plot is bad, far from it, but as good as it is it simply cannot match up to the plot of the first game.Also, the villain (Dr Sophia Lamb) is less compelling or menacing than Andrew Ryan. She is still a compelling character, but less so. Dr Lamb represents the polar opposite of Ryan, espousing the view that all should work together and sacrifice for the common good, to the degree where they lose all autonomy and become little more than drones in a hive.Overall, i would say that this game isn't quite as good as the original, but still manages to be a brilliant game and a sure classic in a trilogy of classics.

												I don't think enough people give this game credit. All I heard was that this Bioshock was weak, lame, etc. However, it's pretty clear that it is NOT a true sequel to Bioshock, simply another story that takes place within the same location at a different time. There are small details connecting the two within the game but neither story has anything to really do with the other.Gameplay was familiar so there was no learning curve but fighting Big Daddies and Big Sisters became a challenge. Still too many Plasmids to choose from and use, plus everytime you equip one, it seems to change which is binded to which key, which made utilizing them effectively a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥Playing the perspective of a Big Daddy was very cool and certainly a different atmosphere from playing Bioshock. Controls are smooth, game looks nice, it feels different and familiar all at the same time. My only real gripe with the game is that it crashed as I was trying to finish collecting the ADAM samples to draw out Alexander and had to use the '-dx9' command to jury-rig the game so I could finish.I don't think I have the heart to attempt playing the games again to get the other endings, since the Little Sisters are much too sweet to kill. Being called 'best daddy' even though I'm a chick was just too cute and heart warming.

												If you loved the first BioShock, you're gonna love this. The game takes place 10 years after the last, still in the city of Rapture. You'll notice though, it's changed. I really enjoyed this game when I played it, I always looked forward to playing it :) The gameplay mechanics are similar to the first game with something new, you can now duel wield plasmids and weapons! Let me tell you, it certainly does make a difference. Plasmids are like magic, there are different types (Electricity, fire, freeze, ect). There are a fair amount of weapons, from machine guns to shotguns. In the game, you get to play as a Big Daddy (Known as Delta). This game explores the bond between a little sister and a big daddy and makes it seem much more touching. The characters are great and memorable, the story will get you hooked, and the ending is very emotional (Depending on which of the multiple endings you get). Something very cool that they added is that you can go outside Rapture sometimes! It's pretty neat walking around in the water :) Overall, I really enjoyed this game and I highly recommend this game. I give it a 9/10

Posted: September 30, 2015
												Love it! The story is amazing, graphics are good ('specially compared to the first Bioshock!), controls and combat are pristine.Multiplayer is still somewhat alive! There seems to be quite a few people who play every day, and there are times of day when you'll get to try it out; around 6pm or later. It was always my favorite FPS multiplayer, but the xbox Bioshock 2 community died out a long time ago so it's nice to see people still play it on the PC. What's cool about the pvp is that you can type to people while you kill 'em, so there's a good, nice, hopeful community playing the game, we hope the community grows but it's definitely an older game. I've been playing multiplayer every day for the past week or so, and I rarely have to sit and wait for a game.The PvP is awesome. Out of all the shooters I've played, it's my favorite. Everyone has a pretty good amount of health so it's not just 1shot vs 1shot hiding around a corner camping; it's different. I mean, there's still 1shot combos and stuff but not everyone has perfected that so it's pretty fair. Wielding plasmids and shooting lightning bolts and crossbows, and turning invisible are the coolest things ever.It was difficult to set the controls for an Xbox controller, if anyone has any questions (how to edit the sensitivity of an xbox controller for multiplayer) just message me.Edit: the PvP community isn't as good as I thought lmao, I keep trying to play; I try once every few weeks, but everyone's adopted the Grenade Launcher strategy; it's a 1shot kill basically, it's overpowered and everyone kind of hates it. I haven't been able to progress much in PvP. I really miss the old xbox days when there were a lot of people playing every day. Now all I see are the same people using the same 1shot strategies over and over. Stun + crossbow = instant 1shot. grenade launcher = stun/disorient/1shot/range, and if you suicide yourself with the grenade launcher, the other team doesn't get a kill, and there's no penalty. You can stand outside a room and fling grenades into the room and get multiple kills without even aiming or trying. That's what PvP is right now basically, I wish there was a game mode that doubled the health of players, just so it isn't 1shots, but requires slightly more strategy than Electro Bolt / Crossbow, which barely requires aiming skill

content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												A sequel to the critically acclaimed Bioshock.Bioshock 2 is very similar to its predecessor in many regards. As for location, It is set in the same city with the same aesthetics. It takes place a few years after the events of the first game. If you liked the atmosphere of the first game, then you will like this as well.There are a few new added tweaks or abilities to the enemies. New splicers and different renditions of Big Daddies. The gameplay is generally the same. Receive a goal and go through different rooms to achieve that goal and proceed to the next level. However, this game can seem to drag on for a while, and is often repetitive in nature-- doing the same tasks, traveling to some place on the map...etc. It is as if the goal is a carrot dangling right in front of you, but then leads you for hours. However, the rather repetitive gameplay is made more fun by more "modern" mechanics, like using plasmids along with a weapon, as opposed to toggling between them in the first one. However, as you are playing as a Big Daddy in this game, moving around feels more clunkly than controlling a human character.The plot is pretty straight forward, without a major twist like the other two games in the series. Similar to the other Bioshock games, you learn alot about the plot and the setting through audio recordings found throughout the levels.Overall, if you enjoyed Bioshock 1, then this game is a good buy, especially with the deep discounts during steam sales.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												I played this game at launch, and it was pretty bad. GFWL was a nightmare, there was constant crashing, multiplayer was a buggy mess, and the actual campaign was severely lacking. I probably would have given it an overall rating of 4.8/10. A slightly below average game.When it was updated recently, I gave it another try. I do applaud 2K for releasing the massive patch so long after the game was released. For current owners, they got the Minerva's Den DLC for free, GFWL was removed, Steam achievements were added, several bugs were fixed, and multiplayer was much better. Still not perfect though. Lots of lag and no proper anti-cheat in multiplayer, and lots of crashing in single player. Anyway, on to the main game. The biggest problem I had with the story was that it felt the exact same as the first one. The villain, Sofia Lamb supposedly had entirely different point of view than Andrew Ryan of the original game, but it didn't feel like that because the way she carried out her actions and the way she talked/presented herself was the exact same as Ryan. Some of the endings were a little cliche, the writing for Eleanor had some really cheesy and mediocre moments, and the overall story just didn't feel right. Like, it was all based around this relationship between Eleanor and you, a big daddy. And you're not even her actual father or anything haha. It was just strange. Cool idea, but I think it could have been written better. I do think a few of the added moral choices were a great touch, how a few main characters fates were all dependent on you. Soundtrack was also fantastic. And while the multiplayer is completely unnecessary, when it worked, sometimes it was pretty fun. The whole background was kinda cool, how it all takes place when Rapture goes to♥♥♥♥♥♥ But of course, there's a stupid levelling system tacked onto it which can kill interest quick. Had to grind for so long to get the last few achievements. Gameplay wise, there was definitely an improvement. Instead of having all the different types of tonics, they were just grouped under one general selection. Dual wielding was great, and many of the weapons were a lot of fun to use. However, just like the first one, the movement is clunky, the FOV is awful and the guns still felt sluggish. Graphics are ugly for a 2010 game, and environments were practically identical to the original. Enemy variety was essentially the same, and the constant Big Sister fights were just annoyingly tedious and stupid. I guess I'd give BioShock 2 a flat 6.0/10. It's a decent game. There are definitely improvements from the original, and a few great ideas. However, throughout the campaign, it just really felt like 2K was beating a dead horse. Get it on a sale. As far as the Minerva's Den DLC goes, it gets universal praise everywhere I see it. I really didn't think it was that special to be honest. The story was decent and the pacing was good, but the gameplay just felt like more of the same. I'd give it 5.5/10, it's an above average add-on.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
												Bioshock 2.I've heard that some really don't like it.Maybe they're just like the guys selling bootleg tech at the night markets where I used to go; loud as hell and they make a decent amount of sense, but boy are they annoying.Maybe it's the story; I told my friends about the halfway mark that the story didn't make a lot of sense and can go suck a big fat one, but that becomes much less true towards the end,Maybe it's the gameplay; largely unchanged, only now, as you're playing a prototype Big Daddy, you becomes way more powerful and the horror element just kind of shows itself tokenly, but it is a hell of a lot of fun.You know what I think?It felt underwhelming to the naysayers because Bioshock 1 was just too good.It feels like the Portal problem again.The first one was so good with its story that Bioshock 2 was held to the same standard, but B2's story wasn't as strong as B1's because B1 just set the bar too damn high.Take off your rose-tinted glasses and you'll find a damn fun shooter; slow, maybe, but fun.Refuse to do so and you'll find yourself quite underwhelmed, and I doubt anyone can blame you for that.This game still comes recommended, and anyone who thinks otherwise might perhaps be looking for a story, in which case, go get Bioshock 1.

												There's no Shyamalanian twist in the middle like the first game, and there are no dramatic differences in gameplay, so I can see why people didn't like this game.Of course, rather than being completely different, Bioshock 2 is just better than the first game in just about every way.  -  The weapons and plasmids are cooler, more varied and just more fun to use.  -  The enemies are more varied (much more exciting than just people who shoot at you).  -  The levels are more varied and less filler-y.-  The characters are better explored.-  The plot is intimate and character driven.-  The player character has a much greater stake in the plot than the first game's protagonist.-  You will be made to feel for the villain and her family.

Posted: January 23, 2015
												Bioshock 2.I've heard that some really don't like it.Maybe they're just like the guys selling bootleg tech at the night markets where I used to go; loud as hell and they make a decent amount of sense, but boy are they annoying.Maybe it's the story; I told my friends about the halfway mark that the story didn't make a lot of sense and can go suck a big fat one, but that becomes much less true towards the end,Maybe it's the gameplay; largely unchanged, only now, as you're playing a prototype Big Daddy, you becomes way more powerful and the horror element just kind of shows itself tokenly, but it is a hell of a lot of fun.You know what I think?It felt underwhelming to the naysayers because Bioshock 1 was just too good.It feels like the Portal problem again.The first one was so good with its story that Bioshock 2 was held to the same standard, but B2's story wasn't as strong as B1's because B1 just set the bar too damn high.Take off your rose-tinted glasses and you'll find a damn fun shooter; slow, maybe, but fun.Refuse to do so and you'll find yourself quite underwhelmed, and I doubt anyone can blame you for that.This game still comes recommended, and anyone who thinks otherwise might perhaps be looking for a story, in which case, go get Bioshock 1.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												Overlook by most Bioshock fans, this game is a gem that is extremely well made.  People probably didn't like it because it was made with a different developer and it didn't really have much horror as the first one but with other features, this game still is solid and possibly better.  The story is great and fairly long.  It follows you as a Big daddy who is trying to rescue his little sister and you make moral choices along the way in which affects the ending and what happens during the game.  The gameplay is amazing.  There is alot to do and it added alot from the first game.  I really like all the powers and guns which expanded from the last game.  There is also better side quests and better objects to collect.  It has a nice system for everything and its highly worth.  This game doesn't end there though.  There is a pretty decent multiplayer and its fairly fun but it is not for everyone.  It is still a nice addition.  Its a must have game to play for anyone who likes a different kind of rpg.
